Chambered for the 577-450 martini henry black powder cartridge. Most of the original blueing is intact, though rust has been at work on the rifle. Some deep pitting below the wood line, but nothing significant from a safety standpoint. Light pitting elsewhere on the metal. and browning of the blueing in other places. Wodd shows age and a good deal of use with some repairs on the butt stock. There was some dry rot that was removed from the buttstock and as a result the wood does not head up flush with the reciever. Significant pitting on the stock fore end hook, and a replacement screw. Slight bend in the cleaning rod. The gun is complete and has been restored to working order. Functions fine and shoots, though not incredibly accurate and hits to the right for me. Bore is in accpetable condition with plenty of rifling and even a little shine. Internals are clean. Lots of British proof marks and Nepalese unit markings on the trigger guard. Ammunition is available for this rifle but VERY expensive. Equipment and components for reloading are readily available and cases can be formed from 24 ga. shotshell brass at a significant reduction in cost but not function. Best reloaded with black powder, but many people have had success with reduced smokeless loads and trail boss loads. A very cool British historical arm in great working condition at 124 years old. postcontent:
Up for sale is my AR-15 in 6.5 Grendel caliber. I purchased the upper already built from a seller on gunbroker.com. The upper is a Sun Devil with a smooth black finish as opposed to the andonized finish typical on Sun Devil uppers. The seller told me the barrel is a Lothar-Walther, as is the bolt. I was told round count was under 200; I added another 75 rounds. The barrel was originally threaded for a muzzle break, but he had the threads cut off and the barrel re-crowned by a gunsmith. Hence, the barrel has a slight swell at the muzzle. The handguard is carbon-fiber and beautifully done. I purchased a Y/M National Match chrome bolt carrier group and a DPMS charging handle to complete the upper. I built the lower using a new black andonized Sun Devil lower with their tensioning screw. The buttstock and buffer are DPMS. The trigger is a Timney 3 lb single stage solid held in place by KNS 2nd generation non-rotating stainless trigger pins. The bolt latch, magazine latch and detent pins are DPMS. The grip is a Stark with integral trigger guard (built for bigger hands). Included in the package are: three C-Products 6.5 Grendel clips (one 10 shot stainless and two 20 shot black); 200 pieces of Alexander Arms/Lapua brass (approx. 75 once-fired; remainder new); Forester Ultra two-die set (full-length sizing die and ultra-micrometer seating die); and bullets (140g Hornady A-Max, 129g Hornady SST, 108g Lapua Scenar and 123g Lapua Scenar – each box has at least 75 bullets).

Anyway, he said the load which performed best in this caliber was 108g Scenars over Vihtavuori N133. I finished the build a few months ago and finally found some Vihtavuori N133 two weeks ago. The results of the first three shots from a cold barrel at 100 yards was a "cloverleaf." Follow-up groups were equally impressive (I have photos).
